125.70.text:
>> DAVID J. MALAN: This is CS50,
Harvard University's introduction

129.67.text:
to the intellectual
enterprises of computer science

134.18.text:
Now if you are among those that
every year are sitting here

137.53.text:
with a bit of nerves in your mind, such
that you don't think you belong here,

141.45.text:
you think that most
anyone sitting around you

144.27.text:
knows far more than you, is indeed
more comfortable than you at computer

147.73.text:
science or computers
more generally, realize

150.43.text:
that 78% of the students who now
take CS50 have no prior experience.

156.14.text:
>> Indeed, there's 100 dots there
on the display, 78 of which

159.57.text:
are solid green, which means you,
if you're among that demographic,

163.54.text: are in very good company here on out.

166.42.text:
And if you are instead among the
22% of CS50 students who do indeed

170.32.text:
have prior experience, whether in
high school or some other program,

173.92.text:
realize that you, too, will
be challenged in the course.

176.43.text:
>> Not only do we have different tracks
for students less comfortable and more

179.93.text:
comfortable alike in sections, we
also have so-called hacker editions

183.79.text:
of most problem sets that
will challenge those students

186.08.text:
with that additional experience
to explore similar material

189.65.text:
but from a more
sophisticated perspective.

193.90.text:
Well, ultimately, what's going to
matter as you explore this field is not

197.75.text:
so much where you end up
relative to your classmates,

200.50.text:
but where you yourself end up in
week 12 versus where you begin here

206.72.text:
Now computer science-- well, let's
call it the science of computation--

211.85.text:
where computation is really just a
fancy way of saying, taking some input,

215.91.text:
producing some output, and
doing so by running algorithms,

219.46.text:
sets of instructions for solving
some problem on those inputs

223.70.text:
in order to produce some output or
solution in which you are interested.

228.46.text:
>> So we recently had
occasion to travel out

231.31.text: to California to meet with an alumna.

234.65.text:
And she'd like to speak
to you here on video

237.19.text:
to testify to just how applicable
even just a taste of computer

241.69.text:
science at the
introductory level can be.

243.77.text:
Even if you don't go on to pursue
computer science as a field,

246.87.text:
or even engineering,
or STEM more generally,

249.33.text:
you'll see, in fact, how a certain
course so influenced her life.

252.36.text:
And she only just took it when she
was a senior here at Harvard College.

256.63.text: >> If we could dim the lights for Susan.

264.11.text:
And I took CS50 when I was
a senior at Harvard in 1990.

269.15.text:
I was actually a history
and literature major.

271.22.text:
>> And my junior summer,
I realized that maybe I

276.76.text:
wanted to learn something
about computers.

282.50.text:
It was hard, but it was the
most amazing class I took.

286.94.text: >> It changed how I think about everything.

289.63.text:
And when I graduated from Harvard
in 1990, I went to Silicon Valley.

297.14.text:
And I've been working
in tech ever since.

300.15.text:
DAVID J. MALAN: Now what Susan
didn't mention in this video,

302.65.text:
that it was actually in her
garage that Google itself was

307.42.text:
>> Now we also reached out to our friends
at code.org, an organization that

311.17.text:
over the past year has been
getting people particularly

313.46.text:
excited about computer science
and programming, in particular.

316.52.text:
But it's worth noting that programming
is not computer science per se.

322.09.text:
Rather programming is just a
tool-- with which all of you

324.56.text:
will be all too well
familiar by semester's end--

327.51.text:
such that you can apply not
just to future courses in CS

330.65.text:
but to whatever fields from whence
you're coming, in humanities,

333.67.text:
social sciences, natural
science, or the like.

336.09.text:
>> Indeed, allow a few other
alumni and their colleagues

339.74.text:
to speak to the applicability
of the field that awaits.

352.34.text:
>> BILL GATES: I was 13 when I
first got access to a computer.

357.35.text:
>> JACK DORSEY: My parents
bought me a Macintosh in 1984

361.64.text:
>> MARK ZUCKERBERG: I was
in the sixth grade.

362.99.text: >> SPEAKER 1: I learned to code in college.

364.67.text:
>> RUCHI SANGHVI: Freshman year, first
semester, Intro to Computer Science.

369.08.text:
>> BILL GATES: I wrote a program
that played tic-tac-toe.

371.85.text:
>> DREW HOUSTON: I think it was
pretty humble beginnings.

374.10.text:
I think the first program
I wrote asked things like,

378.70.text:
ELENA SILENOK: I first learned
how to make a green circle

381.07.text: and a red square appear on the screen.

383.67.text:
GABE NEWELL: The first
time I actually had

385.42.text: something come up and say, hello, world.

387.36.text: And I made a computer do that.

390.85.text:
>> MARK ZUCKERBERG: Learning how
to program didn't start off

393.22.text:
as wanting to learn
all of computer science

395.45.text:
or trying to master this
discipline or anything like that.

398.63.text:
It just started off because I
wanted to do this one simple thing.

401.59.text:
I wanted to make something that
was fun for myself and my sisters.

404.34.text: >> And I wrote this little program.

406.40.text:
And then basically just
added a little bit to it.

408.44.text:
And then when I needed
to learn something new,

409.93.text:
I looked it up, either in
a book or on the internet,

412.21.text: and then added a little bit to it.

413.24.text:
>> DREW HOUSTON: It's really not unlike
playing an instrument or something

421.09.text:
So let us now actually
dive in a little deeper.

424.12.text:
What are these inputs and outputs
that we're talking about here?

429.11.text:
You probably know, even if you have
no familiarity with computer science

432.12.text:
whatsoever, that computers somehow use
and understands only zeros and ones.

436.57.text:
But how can that possibly be given how
much today's desktops and laptops alike

441.28.text:
>> The DNA of the day, the only
alphabet that they understand

444.31.text: is a zero or a one.

447.47.text:
We, humans, tend to use the
decimal system. "Dec" meaning 10.

450.84.text:
And that's 10 because we have
10 digits, 0 through nine.

453.97.text:
>> Now computers, by contrast,
tend to use binary.

457.27.text: So they tend to use only zero and one.

459.56.text:
But it turns out, that even
just with zeros and ones, that

462.68.text:
is a sufficiently large alphabet
with which to represent most

465.90.text:
any piece of data you want,
whether it's a number,

468.49.text:
whether it's a letter, whether it's
a graphic or video on the screen.

472.10.text:
>> Consider, for instance, how we humans
typically interpret this number here.

477.14.text:
This is just three
digits, one, two, three.

480.01.text:
But we know this number
innately now as 123.

485.51.text:
>> Well, if you think back
to perhaps grade school,

487.57.text:
you probably were taught to think of
these numbers as being in columns,

491.70.text:
where the one is in the hundreds
place, the two is in the tens place,

494.70.text: and the three is in the ones place.

497.79.text:
Well, think about the
super simple arithmetic

499.67.text:
that we all have been
doing for years now.

502.22.text:
Effectively, if you've got
a one in the hundreds place,

504.51.text:
you do the quick math 100
times 1 plus 10 times 2--

509.61.text:
because two is in the tens
place-- plus 1 times 3--

513.06.text: because three is in the ones place.

514.83.text:
So, of course, if we
actually multiply this out,

517.04.text:
what we're really representing
with this pattern-- one

519.60.text:
two three-- is 100 plus 20 plus
3, which, of course, is 123.

526.15.text:
>> Now binary, and computers really,
fundamentally speak the same language

531.68.text: They just have a smaller alphabet.

533.40.text:
So computers only have zeros
and ones at their disposal.

537.10.text:
So whereas we humans have essentially
powers of 10 in each of these places--

542.50.text:
10 to the zero, 10 to the one, ten
to the two, giving you 110 and 100

547.70.text:
>> Because computers only have two values
they can understand, zero and one,

552.14.text:
they have to use different values
in these columns, one, two, four.

556.60.text:
And if we kept going, eight,
16, 32, 64, and so forth.

560.48.text:
But the pattern and the
mentality is exactly the same.

564.22.text:
>> So by this logic, anyone, how would
I go about representing the number

568.53.text:
If you've never even thought about
this before, what's your gut say?

575.66.text:
We just need a one in the
ones place because the zeros

578.10.text:
suffice to give us
neither a four nor a two.

580.61.text: So one times one equals one.

582.44.text: Now things get a little interesting.

583.94.text:
If I want to represent in
binary the number two-- but,

586.83.text:
again, even if you've never
spoken this language before,

589.79.text:
how do we represent in binary
the value we humans know as two?

595.57.text:
Just put the one in the
column that you want it.

597.62.text:
>> Now it's getting pretty
easy probably now.

599.56.text:
So if I want to represent three--
there is no three's column.

602.95.text:
So, again, I can now add these values
together by putting a one here.

606.77.text:
So 2 times 1 plus 1
times 1 is, of course, 3.

610.32.text:
>> Now things get a little fun in
that the ones now become zeros.

613.48.text: And to represent four, I get this.

615.48.text:
And if we increment slowly
here-- that would be five.

622.10.text:
>> But now I seem to have
run into a problem.

625.31.text:
How might I go about representing
eight-- would be the next value.

630.52.text: Yeah, so we need a new bits.

631.90.text:
And, indeed, if you've
heard this phrase before,

633.90.text:
bits, that's just short for
binary digit, zero or one.

637.38.text:
>> And so I happen to be representing
only three such bits here.

641.52.text:
But if I had a way of storing not
three different bits, but four,

644.90.text:
surely I could represent
eight, and then nine, and then

649.40.text:
>> But that then calls
into question how we can

652.14.text:
go about representing these
things in the first place.

654.54.text:
It's one thing to draw
them up here on a slide,

656.95.text:
but how do you represent them
if you're a mechanical device?

660.66.text:
What is a computer doing to
represent the inputs and outputs that

664.39.text:
fundamentally define computation
at the end of the day?

669.02.text:
>> Well, what about something
super simple like this?

673.20.text:
And I can trigger this
light bulb to go on

675.46.text:
by turning some electricity
on and allowing electrons

677.92.text:
to flow through, which changes its
state or its value, so to speak.

682.59.text:
For instance, this is
an old school desk lamp

684.46.text:
here with one such
light bulb inside of it.

687.25.text:
And right now it's not
really doing anything useful.

689.94.text:
But as soon as I plug it
into an electrical socket

692.68.text:
and then use this switch-- or
we can even call it a transistor

696.39.text:
or think of it as such--
I can now represent either

699.97.text:
this value, where the light bulb's
obviously off, or this value.

707.52.text:
>> So inside of a computer, presumably,
are much smaller pieces of hardware,

711.22.text:
but that at the end
of the day simply have

712.97.text:
to use electricity--
perhaps capture it--

715.36.text:
and then either keep something
on or keep something off.

719.73.text:
Of course, this isn't
particularly interesting to do

722.02.text: with just a single light bulb.

723.27.text:
>> In fact, how high can I count in
binary with this desk lamp here?

728.55.text:
I need more desk lamps if I
actually want to count higher.

731.02.text: But we can do better than that.

732.21.text:
Because the light bulbs that
we've put in these things

734.46.text:
are actually fancier light bulbs
than yesteryear would allow.

737.73.text:
And they're actually
networked light bulbs.

740.31.text:
And bunches of companies
make these things these days.

743.16.text:
>> But it turns out that
this one in particular

745.19.text:
comes with a feature whereby
you can change its colors.

747.68.text:
So for instance, if you
adorned your dorm room

750.81.text:
with a few of these light
bulbs, depending on your mood,

753.20.text:
depending on who comes in,
depending on the weather,

755.37.text:
depending on the time
of day, you can actually

757.36.text:
change the colors of
the bulbs in your room.

760.30.text:
And that's because these light
bulbs and others like it have what's

763.74.text:
called an API, an application
programming interface, which

768.01.text:
is a topic with which you'll be well
familiar with by semester's end.

770.92.text:
>> And this is just a fancy,
cryptic way of saying,

773.71.text:
you can program these light
bulbs to do your bidding.

777.57.text:
You can send them messages
just like you, a human,

780.36.text:
can send a message to a web server
saying, give me today's news

785.11.text:
>> You can send more arcane
messages to these light bulbs

788.01.text: to say, turn on and turn off.

789.70.text: But that's not all that interesting.

791.37.text:
You can say, turn on red,
turn on green, turn on blue,

794.28.text: all with the same light bulb.

795.99.text:
And you can even, with a bit more
savvy, say, turn yourself to blue

800.99.text:
when it's a gloomy day
outside, for instance.

804.71.text:
It can actually patch into
a weather API and find out

807.91.text:
what the weather is, or the time
of day, or other such triggers.

812.26.text:
>> So, in fact, two of
CS50's own staff members,

815.55.text:
Dan Bradley and Ansel
Duff here, kindly procured

818.83.text: us a whole bunch of these light bulbs.

820.41.text:
And they built CS50's
first ever binary bulbs,

822.91.text:
where we've represented here--
with these playful little magnets--

826.85.text:
the various placeholders we
alluded to just a bit ago.

829.78.text:
>> So way over here is the
ones place, two, four.

832.57.text: And we didn't see higher than that.

834.03.text: But, of course, they're powers of two.

839.49.text:
So if I now want to be a little fancier
than using this old school switch,

843.32.text:
I have here on this iPad
a super simple interface

847.31.text:
that Dan Bradley, a former
student and now teaching fellow,

850.44.text:
programed using some HTML
and JavaScript, which

853.51.text:
are markup and programming
languages respectively.

855.69.text:
And you can probably
see-- even in the back--

857.56.text:
there's a big plus and a big minus,
plus one button for each of these bulbs.

861.67.text:
And what this is going to allow me to
do is, for instance, click the plus

865.74.text:
and now represent, of
course, what number?

868.75.text: And I can hit it again.

876.88.text:
>> And here now we get that rollover,
but we have a fourth bit this time,

882.18.text: So we could do this for quite some time.

884.00.text:
In fact, as an aside,
how high could we count?

891.42.text:
Don't worry too much about the math for
now, but that's a pretty decent number.

894.90.text:
But it actually does bound just
how many pieces of information,

899.14.text:
like a letter, or a graphic
that we could represent.

902.70.text:
I'm going to go ahead
and turn them all off.

904.53.text:
And if I could, I'd like to ask for
a volunteer, our first volunteer--

911.34.text:
The catch is you have to be
comfortable appearing, as you clearly

914.05.text:
are in front of all your classmates,
as well as on the internet.

917.42.text:
And let me look a little beyond the--
how about here in the white shirt?

925.82.text:
So what there is also on this
iPad is a button called Game Mode.

929.82.text:
And this Game Mode is
going to allow me to input

932.57.text:
in advance a particular decimal
number, the numbers we humans are

936.76.text:
And then you will be challenged
here to use the buttons

939.82.text:
on the top-- one for
each of these bulbs--

942.14.text:
to actually figure out
the pattern of light bulbs

945.05.text: that represents the number in question.

946.97.text: >> And I'm sorry, what was your name again?

949.74.text:
>> So let me go ahead and program in
for the world to see the number 15.

954.58.text: We'll keep it small at first here.

956.36.text: And I'm going to go into Game Mode.

958.24.text:
And I'm going to specify,
give us the number 15.

961.90.text:
And now with everyone watching-- if
you want to maybe stand this way,

965.51.text:
because it will line up-- go ahead and
toggle the eight buttons along the top

969.97.text:
to turn the bulbs on
or off as you see fit.

973.53.text:
>> DAVID J. MALAN: And no cheating
by hitting plus 15 times.

977.72.text: Oh, we are going to do that.

980.61.text:
>> DAVID J. MALAN: You can also turn
the light bulbs on individually

982.66.text: with each of these buttons on top.

989.10.text:
So let's pause for the
audience to engage here.

991.28.text:
What number is Jackie
currently representing?

999.63.text: So we have our first winner.

1002.45.text:
>> And we thought we'd have
some fabulous giveaways.

1008.20.text:
If you'd like to be one such
dorm room here on campus,

1010.86.text:
you can yourself have a final project
using now this API, thanks to Jackie.

1021.69.text:
>> --if we could, one more
such around of this.

1024.84.text: Oh, now everyone wants some light bulbs.

1027.69.text:
For the so-called hacker edition,
we're going to ramp it up a-- oh,

1032.77.text:
I think you're coming up now
if your hand's going down.

1037.42.text: DAVID J. MALAN: Alex, come on over here.

1039.44.text:
So for Alex, we are going to
program in a slightly larger number.

1049.74.text:
DAVID J. MALAN: But, as
I said-- and you might

1051.66.text:
want to stand here so
that the buttons line up

1053.58.text:
as you would expect-- but I did
call this the hacker edition.

1078.57.text:
>> You will be able to turn
them off if you-- OK.

1088.73.text: I suppose I should pay up.

1092.33.text:
>> So the ultimate takeaway
here is hopefully, frankly,

1095.55.text:
the simplicity-- the
simplicity with which

1098.11.text:
you can get some nice light
bulbs, apparently in [INAUDIBLE].

1100.65.text:
But they represent,
ultimately, the same ideas

1103.00.text:
with which we humans are
already all too familiar.

1106.31.text:
So what might the next
step be in the progression

1108.66.text:
of trying to do something
interesting with data

1110.92.text:
and representing inputs that aren't just
numbers but are maybe letters or more?

1114.95.text:
>> Well, it turns out that the
computer world, for many years,

1117.82.text:
simply adopted an arbitrary but a
consistent standard that maps numbers

1124.61.text:
For instance, here is an
excerpt from that mapping.

1128.35.text:
A-S-C-I-I. And that is simply a
table that maps uppercase letters--

1133.22.text: in this case-- to decimal numbers.

1137.89.text:
Well, if you actually want to represent
something like an email or some text

1141.09.text:
on a web page, you
obviously want to show

1143.31.text:
the human letters of the
alphabet, not numbers.

1146.10.text:
So depending on the
context of the program

1149.14.text:
that a user is using, if it's
a web browser or email client,

1152.60.text:
numbers can certainly be
interpreted as letters.

1156.09.text:
That is to say, patterns of bits can
easily be interpreted as letters.

1160.29.text:
>> And so what we can have
is the letter A being

1164.70.text:
represented as 65, B
being represented as 66.

1168.41.text:
So if we have a super
short word, like hi,

1170.90.text:
what a computer would ultimately
store in decimal but really in binary,

1175.74.text:
using some sequence of bits, leveraging
a bit of electricity in some way,

1180.07.text: would be the two numbers 72 and 73.

1184.01.text:
>> But the pattern of bits that
represents those values.

1186.78.text:
So these then are how we can
represent our inputs and outputs.

1189.82.text:
And suffice it to say, we can
do more complex representations

1192.63.text:
ultimately with things like
graphics, videos, music, and more

1196.45.text: as we'll see later this term.

1198.19.text:
>> So that just leaves then
algorithms, these sets

1200.63.text:
of instructions with which
we're solving actual problems.

1203.49.text: We're passing in inputs to algorithms.

1205.82.text:
And those algorithms are producing
outputs, hopefully correct outputs

1209.63.text:
and hopefully, too,
efficiently gathered outputs.

1214.16.text:
In other words, it's one thing
to implement something correctly.

1216.89.text:
It's another thing to implement
something well or efficiently.

1220.79.text:
>> For instance, one demonstration
that we're fond of in the course

1224.46.text:
But these things are getting
increasingly hard to find.

1226.35.text:
But this is indeed an old school
phone book, inside of which

1228.93.text:
are 1,000 plus pages of
names and telephone numbers.

1232.58.text:
And if I wanted to look up
someone in this phone book,

1234.83.text:
I could simply do a
very naive algorithm.

1238.64.text:
I could open up to the first page, and
I could start to look for, say, someone

1243.13.text:
And if he's not on the first
page, I progress to the second,

1246.16.text:
and then to the third, and then
to the fourth, and so forth,

1249.12.text: until I finally find Mike Smith.

1254.25.text:
If he's in there, I'll
eventually find him.

1256.04.text:
But it's arguably not very
efficient, certainly not fast,

1258.82.text:
because, my god, why am I
wasting my time flipping

1261.20.text:
through all of these pages when I could
certainly do this physically faster?

1264.50.text:
>> Well, a slight optimization, so to
speak, might be not one page at a time,

1274.03.text:
>> DAVID J. MALAN: So no if I for
instance skip over Mike Smith.

1277.04.text:
But so long as I back pedal
one page, if I overshoot him,

1280.53.text:
maybe we could correct what
might otherwise be a gotcha.

1288.01.text:
It's literally twice as fast
if I do two pages at a time.

1290.95.text:
So if I originally had 1,000 pages,
now I only have to flip 500 times,

1295.72.text:
not fully 1,000 pages to get
potentially in the worst case

1299.43.text:
to the end of the phone
book, where someone

1301.22.text:
like Mike Smith or someone with
a later name might actually be.

1304.38.text:
>> But, of course, we
humans certainly aren't

1306.54.text:
going to be doing that, certainly
not at this point in our lives.

1309.25.text:
What is a reasonable
human likely going to do?

1311.45.text: AUDIENCE: Go straight to the9 S's.

1312.87.text: DAVID J. MALAN: Go straight to the S's?

1313.86.text: How do I go straight to the S's?

1317.34.text:
DAVID J. MALAN: Well,
there's no marking.

1319.05.text:
So, yes, if there were indeed
a label or a sticky tab for S,

1325.42.text:
